newsitem.title: USA: Lawsuit against Destron, Schering-Plough withdrawn.
newsitem.headline: Lawsuit against Destron, Schering-Plough withdrawn.

text.p: Destron Fearing Corp said Tuesday that a lawsuit alleging patent infringements and unfair competition by it and its distributor, Schering-Plough Corp, has been withdrawn.

Destron said the suit was filed in U.S. District Court for Minnesota by three of Destron's competitors -- Trovan Ltd, Electronic Identification Devices Ltd, and TraceNET Technologies Inc -- collectively known as TraceNET Group.

In its complaint, the TraceNET Group claimed the sale of readers and the reading of implantable microchips by Destron and Schering-Plough infringed on three patents covering implantable microchips and reader technology which TraceNET previously sold in the United States under the InfoPET brand name, Destron said.
The TraceNET Group also claimed unfair competition by Destron and a right to an implied license to use and sell microchips that are covered by Destron's patented technology, the company said.

"The abrupt withdrawal of this action approximately 40 days after the complaint was filed is consistent with our position that the claims were completely without merit," said Randolph Geissler, president and chief executive of Destron.
Destron manufactures electronic and visual identification devices for animals.
